issue.title: #365 Simplified the API to get an argument in custom Answer's

repository.name: mockito
repository.description: Most popular Mocking framework for unit tests written in Java

issue.body:
This pull request fixes # 365 by introducing `T getArgument(int)` and deprecating `T getArgumentAt(int,Class<T>)` in type `InvocationOnMock`. This improves the readabilty of custom Answers. 

Now we can write: `String text = invocation.getArgument(1)` 
Instead of: `String text = invocation.getArgumentAt(1,String.class)`

rename.from: The Class/2nd argument of InvocationOnMock.getArgumentAt(int,Class<T>) should be removed.
rename.to: Simplify the InvocationOnMock-API to get a casted argument

issue.title: Fixes #365 Simplify the InvocationOnMock-API to get a casted argument

repository.name: mockito
repository.description: Most popular Mocking framework for unit tests written in Java

issue.body:
This pull request fixes #365 by introducing `T getArgument(int)` and deprecating `T getArgumentAt(int,Class<T>)` in type `InvocationOnMock`. This improves the readabilty of custom Answers. 

This...
`String text = invocation.getArgumentAt(1,String.class)` 
can be replaced by... 
`String text = invocation.getArgument(1)`

issue.title: Changes to InvocationOnMock API should include version info

repository.name: mockito
repository.description: Most popular Mocking framework for unit tests written in Java

issue.body:
PR #365 added a new method, `getArgument`, to `InvocationOnMock`, and deprecated `getArgumentAt`, but the new docs do not mention the version at which the new method was added and from what version the deprecation is in effect. This is confusing for users who are still using the 1.10.x series when using the Javadocs on the mockito.org website (which just shows the latest docs).

A quick update to the docs in `InvocationOnMock` will solve this. I haven't yet noticed other instances of this, but a quick sweep of the recent changes might be worth doing, to see if the same sort of update needs to be done elsewhere.

issue.title: getArgumentAt is removed in 2.7.6

repository.name: mockito
repository.description: Most popular Mocking framework for unit tests written in Java

issue.body: I could not find this method in 2.7.6 version of InvocationOnMock and there is also no information in the release notes in the [incompatible-changes](https://github.com/mockito/mockito/wiki/What%27s-new-in-Mockito-2#incompatible-changes-with-110). Are you going to add it again or what was the reason to remove?

body:
I would like to mention that sometimes class argument can be useful.

In my case I would like to catch object passed to mock and write to mongo database.
The code I would like to have is:

```
// test setup
doAnswer(invocation -> mongoTemplate.insert(invocation.getArgument(0, Person.class)))
  .when(mock)
  .myMethod(any());

// test execution 
mock.myMethod(new Person("Joe", "Doe"))
```
The reason of problem is that `MongoTemplate` has 2 similar methods:
```
public <T> ExecutableInsert<T> insert(Class<T> domainType) {...) //(1)
public void insert(Object objectToSave) {..) //(2)
```
AFAIU, when I setup `doAnswer(invocation -> mongoTemplate.insert(invocation.getArgument(0))`, type inference will choose method (1) and finally I get class cast exception `Person` -> `Class`

Unfortunately, code `doAnswer(invocation -> mongoTemplate.insert((Person)invocation.getArgument(0))` does not compile

To implement my test, I have to define anonymous class `Answer` so my code is long-winded - one-liner looks much better

issue.title: Add back InvocationOnMock.getArgument<T>(int, Class<T>)

repository.name: mockito
repository.description: Most popular Mocking framework for unit tests written in Java

issue.body:
In https://github.com/mockito/mockito/issues/365 we replaced the existing `getArgumentAt<T>(int, Class<T>)` API with the current `getArgument(int)` API. However, when integrating this change within Google, we ran into numerous issues.

An example:

```java
invocation.getArgumentAt(0, Runnable.class).run()
```

gets rewritten to

```java
invocation.getArgument(0).run()
```

This does not compile, as the generic parameter is erasured to `Object` and thus does not have the `run` method.

Therefore, I would propose adding back an overload to `getArgument` that allows you to specify the `Class`. In general, users would not need this inside a variable assignment, but do need it in all other cases.
